speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We'll hear argument now in Garcetti v. Ceballos. Ms. Lee.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, that's -- I mean, I can see - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Do you think that the Court tried to apply the Pickering test?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Do you think that the Pickering test, properly applied, would have reached a different result in this case?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: It could have - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: -- certainly.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Do you think that the proper application of Pickering would yield a different result in this case?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Could it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Counsel, you've made the point that if we go the Ninth Circuit way, every time an employee gets in Dutch there's a potential first amendment issue. Why hasn't that been a problem since 1988 in the Ninth Circuit? I think 1988 was the year of the Circuit's Roth decision. So, we haven't seen a deluge, and doesn't that rather discount your argument?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: No.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: I realize that, but that -- as I understand it, that has been true since the Ninth Circuit's Roth decision in 1988. And apparently we have not seen a deluge of these claims, or we would have had citations to the cases. So, doesn't that rather discount the concern that you express?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: But didn't -- maybe I'm wrong on my assumption, but didn't the Ninth Circuit take that position, back in 1988?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Okay.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: What do you do with a public university professor, who -- is fired for the content of his lectures? Certainly, in the course of his employment, that's what he's paid to do. That has no first-amendment protection?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: "Should not be entitled, presumptively, to first-amendment protection," what does that mean? That there might be first amendment protection, in light of the particular context - -

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- of the speech?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I suppose that, in the situation the Chief Justice mentioned, the professor would still be able to contend that the university fired him because it disagreed with the political content of his speech or because of the university's politics. He could still make that claim, couldn't he?  --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But the - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- burden would be on him, as it would be in most cases - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- to show that that was true.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Whereas, the Ninth Circuit would put it on the -- put the burden on the university to show that it wasn't true.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I would have thought you might have argued that it's speech paid for by the Government, that's what they pay him for, it's their speech; and so, there's no first-amendment issue at all.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But in Rust v. Sullivan, the Government was buying a commodity. It was the Government's program, and it was employing people, funding people to implement that program. Here is a person whose job includes being candid, serving justice, serving truth.  If that's part of his job responsibilities, that's quite different from speaking the speech that the Government wants spoken.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I guess if your job is to speak truth, and you speak falsehood, that's a good reason to fire you, which is what happened here.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: But you don't - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- contend that, do you?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Do you contend - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- that his statement was false? Do you contend the speech was false?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, but how do we know that? We're at summary judgment.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: No, I realize that, but where do you -- how do you infer, from that, that the individual, the employee, was not telling the truth?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: If - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- if I - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- if my ethical record amounted to a lie every time I made a -- an inaccurate prediction about what a court was going to do when I was a young lawyer, I would have had a very short career. [Laughter.]

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: And that seems to me as much as you can infer from what this individual did.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Oh. Oh. Okay.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: So, we don't - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- we don't know why it didn't pan out the way he said it was going to, and we don't know that he was -- that he was lying.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Okay.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You don't have to establish that he was lying; just that his prediction -- his job, was to predict, and he made a -- an erroneous -- a false prediction. Don't have to show that he intended to do that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Yes, but the disposition by the -- I mean, his grievance by the hearing examiner was that there was no retaliation. He assumed that the speech was proper and there was no inefficiency or misconduct on the part of the speaker.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: And, in my understanding, that was the only defense that was made for the charge, that,  "We didn't retaliate." There was no claim that the speech was improper in any way. Am I wrong on that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: So, we assume, for purposes of our case, that what he said was totally accurate and did not, itself, provide the basis for saying he was incompetent or something of that -- like that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Can I ask you one - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Excuse me, I'm not sure I understood the answer to the first question, John. Was he not fired because he had made an improper assessment?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: No.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And your defense is that the - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- actions were not taken with any reference to this -- to this at all.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But that's surely a - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- surely a factual inquiry, which will be disputed. If you want to win on summary judgment, it seems to me you have to establish that, assuming he was fired because of this speech, that would be -- or not promoted because of his speech -- that would be perfectly okay.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That's where - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- we are.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: We assume - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- that that was the reason for the later actions.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But what is your position?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Ms. Lee, is your position that job-required speech -- an assistant district attorney's obligation is to give his best opinion -- that job-required speech is outside the first-amendment protection? You say the Ninth Circuit went too far, in one way. But are you saying that as long as it's related to his job, it's simply not protected by the first amendment? Is that your position?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Yes, I understand - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- I understand that, but I was confused by your answer to Justice O'Connor, because the question was, Would this come out a different way under Pickering? And I take it your answer is, this doesn't come in the door, because he's not speaking as a citizen.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: I'm confused. You think that this -- there was an aspect of it that was citizen speech? Why - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Well, what do you mean - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- by "the balance, weigh in favor"? Because, a moment ago, I thought you answered me, "This kind of speech simply is not shielded by the" - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- "first amendment."

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: You would give - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- greater protection to a public speech than to a comment from -- on the job from -- to one's superior. Can you give me an example of a statement that would provide -- be entitled to complete first-amendment protection if made in a speech, but could justify a discharge if made face to face with your employer?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Could you give me an example of a statement that would be protected in a public speech, but, if made privately to your superior, could provide the basis for a discharge?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Which was - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- protected.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: You're not - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- responding to my question. My question is, Can you give me an example of a statement that would be entitled to protection if made in a public speech, but could be a basis for discharge if made face to face?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: No, I'm - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- asking you if - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- what he says privately could the basis for a discharge. Surely, he couldn't be discharged for what you just described.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Is that - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- is that true in this case? I realize they didn't get to it on summary judgment, but is that true in this case with respect to a Brady disclosure?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: What if -- what if the lawyer simply believes that he has an ethical obligation to make the disclosure, and he makes it, and he is then subject to retaliation? No first amendment claim on his part?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, does that mean -- what's your answer to my question? If he makes the Brady disclosure because he believes that is an ethical obligation, and he is then subject to retaliation, does he have a first amendment claim, or not?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you - -

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- Ms. Lee. Mr. Himmelfarb.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: What's your answer to that last question, Mr. Himmelfarb?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: So, no free-speech protection under Pickering.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: And how about this case? Could it not be resolved under a proper handling of Pickering?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Now, what about retaliation claims that the employee may have? What about whistleblower-type claims by an employer? Are they -- are they separate from the first-amendment concerns?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What if the reason -- what if the reason for the -- for firing him is that he's a Democrat and it's a Republican Administration, and the speech is used as the pretext?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Suppose that we have an instance where it is job related. He is not speaking as a private citizen, and it's also a public concern. Now, in such an instance, could we say that, at least if the matter of public concern rise to the level where it's related to an independent constitutional protection -- say, founded in the due-process clause -- under those circumstances, the employer cannot unreasonably -- though  we give him an area of discretion, he cannot unreasonably retaliate.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Why not?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Why not? And here is an independent obligation.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: It's very unusual - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- but it's there.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: You'd only lose -- the Government would lose, only where you can conclude that they could -- "they," the Government -- could not -- could not reasonably conclude that he'd been insubordinate.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So, we covered the case of the Democrat, Republican, et cetera. In other words, we'd  give him -- should we give him total discretion? Can't we limit that discretion of the supervisor?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: But, Mr. Himmelfarb, in that case he could also be fired if he made the statement in a speech, could he not?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: But could he not be fired if the scenario you just described as - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: It seems to me odd that the employee has greater protection if he goes outside the regular channels and makes a speech than if he does -- he  -- goes right to his superior and says, "I think this is what's wrong and should be remedied."

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: You may have no constitutional protection. But if you go ahead and make a speech, you do.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: And it's going to be clear that that's violating your job, and it has an adverse impact on your job-related duties, because you're going public, instead of going through the channels.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: But he has less constitutional protection.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: How comfortable are you that this line you're trying to draw is one that's going to be workable in practice? I mean, suppose the employee writes a memo, and the boss comes and says, "If you don't promise me you're not going to talk about this publicly, you're fired." And he says, "Well, I'm not going to promise that." And so, he's fired. Now, is that internal, or is that external?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Right.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: That's - -

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- required by his job. But "promise that he's not going to talk about it" is not required by his job. And this case, kind of, raises the question, because the only reason it's squarely presented on the memo is because the Court didn't reach the Brady disclosure or the talk to the bar association that were related to the memo.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I suppose you have the rule which distinguishes between employment-related and outside speech, under the hypothetical -- difficult hypothetical posed by the Chief Justice, it would be an -- the promise would be an unconstitutional condition, or something like that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I suppose it's a hard case - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And I suppose that what constitutes a matter of public interest is not the clearest line in the world either, is it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Do you -- let me ask you this -- do you propose drawing the line -- or at least drawing a line in some circumstances this way: That, at step one, if it can be concluded that a private communication between the employer and the employee would have constituted the discharge of the employee's assigned work -- so that it would have been within the scope of his employment, and, therefore, not subject to Pickering balancing, if he had made the statement to the employer --  that, therefore, the statement cannot be regarded as a statement of public interest, even if he had disclosed it publicly, or if he took a further step and went to the bar association and whatnot?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: But if it is within -- I'm sorry, but if it -- if it is within the speaker's assigned duties as an employee, does that preclude a conclusion, later on, that he was speaking as a citizen, even if he goes public with it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: So, we do have, then, the problem that Justice Stevens has raised.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: What about the hearing at which this office had testified? I thought that part of the complaint was, "When I spoke at the hearing, I was speaking in a public forum, and they fired me for it."

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Himmelfarb. Ms. Robin-Vergeer.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, it - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, I'm not sure that that was clear from the decisions of this Court. Certainly, that wasn't what was involved in Pickering. That was  outside speech.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And the same -- and the same with Connick. So, I'm -- if you're saying that this is what the circuits have understood, fine, but that's not this -- that's why we took this case.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And I think all the cases did say "expressing views as a citizen on a matter of public concern." Wasn't that qualifier always used?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So, what does it mean? What is -- what is your explanation for that qualifier, "expressing views as a citizen"? Why do we - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- continually say that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, let's assume that - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- I think that that's an open  question under Pickering, and that this case presents it. Do you -- do you concede -- and maybe you don't -- that there is any category of first amendment speech, as a matter of public concern, which an employee cannot direct to the employer? Are there -- are there some matters as to which the employer can protect its own interests and stifle the employee's speech?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: So, there's always Pickering balance.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Ms. Lee -- Ms. Lee told us that the Ninth Circuit weighed the capacity of the plaintiff as an employee, rather than a member of the public, in favor of the employee and against the employer. Is that how you read the Ninth Circuit's decision?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- any comment that an employee makes regarding how the office is working is a matter of public concern. I would concede that. I mean

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- that has to be.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And the consequence of your view is to have the first amendment being used for courts to monitor the discussions that take place in every public agency -- local, State, and Federal -- in the United States. It's -- you are advocating a sweeping rule. Now,  you'll say, "Oh, well, Pickering balance will protect it."

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But I still think the intrusive consequences of your -- of your rule are sweeping.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I guess our law clerks would meet it every day.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yeah, maybe, maybe not. I don't - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- anything that goes on in my chamber that isn't a matter of public concern, and I would think everything at OSHA and everything at -- look, I'll -- let me put my question to you, because you're going to make an argument that I don't think is too widely shared; namely, that Pickering decides this case. If that's your argument, I'd like to ask you a question based on the assumption Pickering does not decide this case. And it seems to me that Pickering involves a case in which it's both a matter of public concern and outside the scope of employment.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And here we have a case that is a matter of public concern, but inside.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So, in those circumstances, I want to know how you believe the first amendment requires us to decide this case. And as I read this case, in the record, we have one individual, your client, who looked at an affidavit. The affidavit said that the deputy sheriffs were trying to locate where a vehicle that was chocked up came from. They saw tire tracks. The tire tracks went back to a fence at the end of a long driveway. So, I looked in the record. I couldn't find the affidavit. So, I assume that's what it says. And I wanted to know what the deputy sheriff said. What they said is that your client agreed that there were tire tracks. There were tire tracks that did not go the whole length of the driveway, but, rather, tire tracks near the house, where they got the search warrant for. And, they added, that -- the deputies -- that there was rocks broken up. All right. So, we have two sides to this argument: the deputies, who might reasonably contend that they did nothing wrong; your client, who thinks they were lying. And we also have a letter that your client wrote,  where he said that these deputies are grossly inaccurate and clearly misleading. Suppose his supervisor goes to him and says, "I think that that letter is not the right tone. Maybe you're right, maybe you're wrong; maybe they're in good faith, maybe they're not. And so, if you don't change that tone, I'm going to discipline you." All right? Now, that's my hypothetical, which seemed to me, perhaps, very much like this case. How, in your opinion, does the first amendment handle such a matter?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But I don't under- --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- I understand the ultimate answer you gave the hypothetical. I don't understand the principle you're following. I mean, it's a matter of --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- you would agree this is a matter of public concern.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Which is what I'm looking - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- for. I'm looking for - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- a standard.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But we don't have a standard.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But in Justice - -

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- in Justice Breyer's hypothetical, if the employee filed a lawsuit claiming a violation of his first-amendment rights, you would say that could not be thrown out, on summary judgment, on the ground that the speech was within the scope of his employment.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: No.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No, no there is --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, that would - -

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- be a dispute of fact, so it probably wouldn't -- so it wouldn't be thrown at summary judgment at all.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Look --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I'm not making my question too clear. I imagine the district judge. I get just the facts I described to you. Your client, who's very upset, says, "This is the most unreasonable thing that ever happened. They were trying to prevent me from communicating with the judge. I'm the one who saw the sheriffs. They didn't." The other side says, "We think  it's reasonable what we did." My question to you is, What standard does that judge apply under the first amendment? What does he do?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: So, the Federal - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- Federal courts supervise the constant dialogue that is the everyday routine practice in every governmental agency, local and Federal, in the United States.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But that would be something that would have to go to trial, to prove that the -- that  the employee was incompetent.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, in - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- in this case, the supervisor said, "There can't be -- can't be tracks on asphalt, so you're probably right." Then he finds out that it's a tire rim, and of course the rim makes a -- so we have to find out this at discovery -- at the discovery stage of a lawsuit?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Why doesn't - -

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- why doesn't Rust answer this question? I mean, there, it was really -- this issue was just outsourced by the Government. They paid for the speech there, and we said that if you pay the piper, you get to call the tune. And this is just an insourced -- the same question.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: He was writing a memo about why the case should be dismissed. Wasn't - -

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- that part of his job?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, why is that? In the -- in your hypothetical, the doctor is -- it's not his job to challenge the restriction on the Government grant, but that's what he's doing, so that's not part of his job. Here, it's part of Ceballos's job to explain why the case should be dismissed, and that's what he wrote in his memo.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: What do you do with your friend's response to that, that in Connick the Court characterized Givhan as involving a case of a citizen complaining about a particular practice?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: We just shouldn't have said "as a citizen" in all of these cases. We were just padding our opinion with unnecessary words.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But then he would be violating the internal rules of the workplace.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Where as giving his candid views -- the search warrant -- he's giving his own opinion. But if he goes outside, he is violating a rule of the workplace. And it would seem to me that there are certainly measures could be taken against him for that.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Do you think he should  have lost under the Pickering balance, in that case, if he went public right away?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: What if he does let the employer try first, and the employer does nothing, then he goes public? Where does the Pickering balance come out then?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: What - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- what you're saying is, is  that the first amendment has an office and a function within the confines of a Government agency that it doesn't have outside. That's a curious calculus. It seems to me that the first amendment has its most application when you talk to newspapers, when you talk outside. That's what the first amendment's about. The first amendment isn't about policing the workplace.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Is any -- is any duty of an employee in a -- an agency devoted to service of the public -- is any of his functions not a matter of public  concern?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It's news. This is a press -- a press kind of a test.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Newsworthy.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: I thought that's - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- what Connick was about, that there are things that are said in the workplace that are of no public interest. They're personal gripes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- so if an employee -- I really don't understand it -- an employee comes forward with some scurrilous information about a family member of his boss, who is a public figure, and his whole families are public figures, which would be picked up by the press, that would be a matter of public concern?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Gee, I never understood that that's what the test was. I thought this was a matter that deals with the welfare of the public, rather than -- rather than the welfare of the press.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, that I understand.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That's the welfare of the public.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: No, he's - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- he's just saying, you know, his boss's wife, a mayor of a big city, is running around with somebody. Okay? And that's picked up by the press. It's there on the gossip pages. She's a public figure. You say that would be covered by this.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Anything that would get in the press. That's it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Wow.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: We live in a world where people are leaking things all the time. And there are thousands of things that are in the public interest every day. But what's bothering me is, while I see the Government's rule as protecting the interests of the employer, it's very hard for me to believe that never is there an instance where the first amendment offers protection. But the only choice you've given me is a rule that says every dispute  of the public interest is going to go right into constitutional litigation. And I don't like that either. So, am I hopelessly - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- forced to choose which is the lesser of the evils, or is there some middle approach that gives discretion to the Government, but doesn't allow them to exceed that discretion in a certain category of cases? If so, what? And - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- how would you phrase it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: So, we do this - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- so we do this as a -- so we do this as a matter of what is sound management principles for a Government agency? How does that relate to the first amendment?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But Government misconduct -- if I get a memo from a law clerk that says, "Justice So-and-So's jurisprudence is wacky," that goes to [Laughter.]

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- that goes to Government misconduct, under your theory, right? And I fire them, because I think that's not appropriate to put in a memo.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: They have a first- amendment claim, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Nobody's wacko here. I mean, it's plainly - - [Laughter.]

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- plainly false.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, they disagree with it. They think it's -- whatever -- unprincipled, wrong.  They write me a memo, and I say, "Don't write me a memo like that." And they write me another one, and then I fire them.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: And they think it's Government misconduct because of the way cases are decided, and that they have a first amendment interest. What could be more important than how the Court decides cases? And that violates their first-amendment rights.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But there was - -

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- a dispute about that in this case, too. I mean, it -- under the supervisor's view, it may come down to simply whether there were tire  tracks or tire rim tracks. And that's not as serious, in one view, as your client thinks it's serious.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Your answer to Justice Breyer's -- I was just going to jump in there -- your answer to Justice Breyer's question is, look at -- if you want to be sure that, in every case, you know, the good cases fall on this side, the bad cases fall on -- he should buy your position that every case should go to a balancing test. That will give you the perfection of first-amendment application. The absolute perfection. Now, it'll cost a  lot of money, and it'll, you know, interfere with a lot of employment things, but it will give you first-amendment perfection. Right? I mean, that's the answer.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Is that your answer?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, that - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: There would -- in this case, unlike any other case I've seen in the employment area, there is a hearing in -- before a court of general  jurisdiction, who goes into this. That's what the criminal trial is for. And he did. There was also a grievance proceeding.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- I've got -- you've got me part of the way. Now, I'm not saying I -- I have to think this through, but you got part of the way. You say here, there's an independent constitutional basis for the speech being permitted. But, now, still within that, the Government agency has to have some authority to discipline a person, even there, because, after all, he might have been accusing these sheriffs of things that were really not justified by what they, in fact, did. Or maybe he was right. What about that part of the standard? Do you want to say that the Government wins, as long as it behaved reasonably? Do you want to say that the Government loses only if there was an abuse of ordinary employer discretion? Do you want to say the Government -- et cetera. What do you want to say?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right. Suppose - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- we were to write this, hypothetically. Indeed, the employer has broad discretion to discipline the employee for the manner -- or whatever he does -- even in such an area, but that discretion can be abused. And, therefore, it is up to the judge to determine whether a jury could find such abuse of discretion here.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: But that does - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- that does mean that potentially -- as the Government says, potentially every case is at least going to get as far as summary judgment in court.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Well, you -- it wouldn't be that way if the rule was that if it's employee speech on the job, it's not protected at all.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: No, that's the argument that's being made here by both the - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Okay, do - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- do we know how many cases of this sort there are?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Yeah.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Yeah.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Over what - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- period of time?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: In - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- in all of the circuits - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- that follow a ninth-circuit kind of rule?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That's court of appeals. You really don't know how many district-court judgments there may have been that didn't go up to the court.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: There's one aspect of this case that no one has touched on. The concurring judge, Judge O'Scannlain, said, this is what whistleblower statutes are supposed to handle, and that if we accepted your view of the first-amendment coverage, the whistleblower statutes would be superfluous.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: California does have a whistleblower statute. Is that right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And there was a claim made under it, but we're not told how it came out.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: There was not.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: He did -- he --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I'm not sure you've answered Justice Ginsburg's question. Her question was, Don't whistleblower statutes cover this? And your answer, if I understood it correctly, is, whistleblower statutes cover this, and a lot more. That doesn't prove - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- that doesn't prove- -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- that they don't take care of this problem.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Some would not cover it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Some are quite narrow - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- of what they cover.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Some of the whistleblower statutes are very specific and narrow - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- of what they cover.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Some of them - -

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- in fact, don't cover disclosures that are job related. If it's the employee's job to blow the whistle on this type of thing, it's usually not covered by a whistleblower statute.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I guess I'm - -

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- thinking of the Federal law, where the idea is, if it's part of your job, you have the normal civil-service job protections if you're being retaliated or discriminated against for doing your job, so you don't get the extra protections of the whistleblower law. The only people who get it are the  people who -- it is not part of their job.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Yeah. Thank you, Ms. Robin-Vergeer.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Ms. Lee, you have one minute left.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Ms. Lee. The case is submitted. [Whereupon, at 11:02 a.m., the case in the above-entitled matter was submitted.]
